ANTH P-16210.course_description: In the United States, more people die every year from opioid overdoses than gunshot wounds and car accidents, and the crisis appears to be worsening and rapidly changing. While most medical research focuses on the biology of disease, this course takes a biosocial approach to unmask how social factors, economic insecurity, and the availability of massive amounts of pharmaceuticals have become an overdose crisis. In the first part of the course, we explore the connection between opioid addiction and crime, especially under conditions of poverty, chaos, and violence. Then, we explore how people search for health care and support when condemned to precarious lives. By investigating the opioid epidemic in this way, students are encouraged to think boldly and creatively beyond the traditional boundaries of medicine; perhaps someone's best medicine is a housing voucher or a testing strip to detect fentanyl. By the end of the course, students understand the social roots of the opioid epidemic and how solutions may be implemented.

ANTH P-16225.course_name: Money and Power: Cultural Approaches to Economic Life
ANTH P-16225.course_description: This course considers how culture shapes the economic aspects of our lives. We seek to understand the economy not as a separate realm with its own special logic and structure but instead as embedded in the social relations, identities, and cultural practices of everyday life. Our major course themes include exchange, money, debt, commodification, markets, and labor. We consider questions such as: how do the different kinds of exchanges we engage in—gift exchanges versus market exchanges, for instance—shape our relationships with others? We explore the social meaning of money and the role of the market in our lives. In a world where it is possible to rent a family, does money destroy love and intimacy? What aspects of our lives are governed by the logic of capitalism and what aspects escape capitalism's grip? Why does it feel shameful to be in debt and how has this shame been manipulated for political purposes? Why in the US do we consider work to be sacred and morally purifying even though many of us have tedious jobs? The course readings include theoretical and empirical works drawn mainly from the fields of anthropology, economic sociology, and heterodox economics.

ASTR P-17210.course_description: Astrophysics is a branch of science that focuses on using physics and mathematics to describe the universe an its contents. This astronomy course delves into the fascinating realm of theoretical astrophysics, exploring the fundamental theories and models that shape our understanding of the universe. We explore the basics of astronomy and astrophysics and answer questions like: what makes the stars shine? What makes a planet habitable? And most importantly, how do we know the things we do about the universe? This course gives students a working knowledge of the physics and prepares them to critically evaluate questions about astronomy and astrophysics.

ASTR P-17221.course_name: Introduction to Machine Learning for Astronomy
ASTR P-17221.course_description: In this course, we use machine learning (ML) to explore exciting problems in contemporary astronomy. Here, we use astronomy as an umbrella term which includes astrophysics and cosmology. Students can expect to receive daily lectures introducing concepts ranging from galaxy classification to the expansion of our universe, as well as on supervised and unsupervised ML algorithms. Students work collaboratively in applying ML to problems in astronomy with daily in-class and homework activities. The course culminates in the presentation of collaborative mini-projects where students have the opportunity to demonstrate their newly acquired expertise.

ASTR P-17235.course_description: Never be lost again! Find your way on sea, land, or air by employing celestial and terrestrial techniques. Acquire expertise in using navigators' tools (sextant, compass, and charts) while learning the steps to the celestial dance of the sun, moon, stars, and planets. This course relies on practical skills, collaborative problem-solving, and journal keeping. Weather permitting, the course culminates in a day-long cruise to practice navigation skills. This course includes minimal lecturing and focuses predominantly on practical activities with individual attention from teaching staff. Math beyond high school trigonometry and geometry is unnecessary.

ASTR P-17240.course_description: In this course, we take a broad yet rigorous look at how we understand our universe, covering everything from stars and planets to cosmology and special relativity. This is done not only through math and physics, but also through the historical lens of the context within which discoveries have been made and the people who made them. Along the way, students work together in and out of class to learn from each other—the way science is really done. Students learn how to solve physics problems in an organized way. Additionally, they have the opportunity to observe with a Harvard undergraduate's telescope and work on finding the answers to their own interesting questions through a final presentation.

ASTR P-17245.course_name: Introduction to Astronomy: Observations and Theory
ASTR P-17245.course_description: In this course, we take a broad look at how we measure and understand our universe, covering the basics of observational astronomy and how it relates to the real physical systems. This course covers topics from celestial sphere to cosmology and from stars and planets to black holes. We look at the math and history of these observations. Along the way, students work together in and out of class to learn from each other—the way science is really done—and learn how to solve physics problems in a systematic way. Students have the opportunity to observe with a Harvard undergraduate telescope and work on finding the answers to their own interesting questions through a final presentation.

ASTR P-17250.course_description: Light is used by astronomers to observe the sky and understand the nature of the objects they observe. Understanding how light behaves has been crucial to the development of new telescopes and instruments and has yielded new theories and discoveries. This course, explores the different descriptions of light through the study of telescopes and instruments. Light viewed as rays is at the heart of geometrical optics, a model extremely useful to study lenses, mirrors, and optical telescopes. The description of light as wave is essential to introducing radio astronomy and helps us to describe the principles spectrographs rely on. The detection of highly energetic gamma rays can be simplified by describing light as a particle. Along the way, we introduce some of the most fascinating aspects of light, such as interference and polarization, and discuss how those can be used to provide valuable information on astronomical objects.

BIOS P-13502.course_description: This course examines the structure and function of the mammalian nervous system by examining the molecules, cells, and circuits that are involved in directing our behavior. We explore how the nervous system is constructed during development, how it adapts with experience throughout life, how it functions in normal behavior, and how it can be disrupted by injury and disease. By the end of the course, students should understand core neurobiological principles while also broadening their perspectives on this field of research.

BIOS P-13503.course_name: The Neurobiology of Motivation: An Introduction to Behavioral Neuroscience
BIOS P-13503.course_description: Why, given the same choices, do different people make different decisions? And why will even the same person make different decisions when repeatedly put in the same situation? In this course we pull back the curtain on the mysterious black box that mediates our decision making to understand how motivation influences behavior. Together we explore what is known about motivation across behaviors and species, and how the systems designed to regulate our behavior can go awry in instances of disease. The course begins by providing students with a basic foundational knowledge in how neurons function and work together. We then see how that knowledge has been applied by researchers to make discoveries about how some of our core, innate behaviors are regulated and examine what happens in instances of disease. The course culminates in a field trip to a behavioral neuroscience lab at Harvard where students are exposed to ongoing cutting edge research in the field.

BIOS P-13504.course_name: Neurobiology: Sensation Does Not Equal Perception
BIOS P-13504.course_description: Our ability to perceive is guided not only by our ability to sense things, but thoughts, feelings, and past experiences that converge to form our own individual reality. In this course, we explore from sensation to perception and how they can be altered. Every step of the way, we challenge what is real and what is being perceived. How can we tell the difference? What role does varying our percepts have on our sense of self? In the first half of the course, our focus is to understand the way the brain senses the world. We start from the beginning of modern neuroscience before an overview of how we move, sense, smell, taste, and build our individual perception of the world. In the second half of the course, we interrogate how percepts can be altered, both changed by the environment around us and by disease that can strip us of our sense of self.

BIOS P-13506.course_description: Have you ever been told to stay off your phone before bed or limit caffeine intake so that you get a better night's sleep? Or maybe you have been wondering what the deal is with mindfulness and meditation—could it really make you happier? From fad diets to rituals that have been practiced for thousands of years, together we explore the biological basis of today's popular health trends. Over the course of four units—nutrition, sleep, exercise, and meditation—we dive deep into the biology of how the choices we make in our everyday lives affect the function of our nervous system. Along the way we develop a foundational understanding of neuroscience topics including the action potential, metabolism, and circadian rhythms. To wrap-up the course students show what they have learned by creating a public service announcement about a health topic of their choice.

BIOS P-13507.course_name: Survival Circuits in the Brain: How Animals Detect and Respond to Danger
BIOS P-13507.course_description: The brain governs what we do, how we feel, and ultimately makes us who we are. This complex system of cells allows us to evaluate our experiences, adapt, and direct behaviors necessary for survival. This flexibility in part arises from the ability of neuronal cells to adjust their physiology, alter connectivity, and tune their responses towards specific stimuli, which ultimately gives rise to distributed networks within the brain that perform critical computations that influence our behavior. In this course, we explore fundamental principles of neuronal cells and circuits, how survival circuits in the brain process sensory information (for example, the sight of a snake) and drive defensive responses (for example, the urge to run), and how scientists use modern approaches to monitor and manipulate (that is, turn on or off) neural activity in freely-behaving animals within the laboratory in attempt to understand the neural basis of behavior.

BIOS P-13508.course_description: The nervous system organizes itself into circuits—ensembles of nerve cells that are specialized for distinct functions. Neural circuits underlie our ability to receive sensory information from our world, process the information efficiently, and execute an appropriate behavioral response. Neurological disorders result from failed or disrupted circuit wiring and greatly impact one's ability to navigate their environment. In this course, we explore the basic concepts of neural circuit assembly and examine how defective circuits result in disease states. We also study the susceptibility of neural circuits to external (such as drugs and trauma) and internal influences.

BIOS P-13511.course_name: Introduction to Cancer: Diving into Research
BIOS P-13511.course_description: This course takes students on a journey through cancer biology, exploring the field from a researcher's perspective. The purpose of the course is to give students a unique view of how scientific research is conducted, focusing on experiments that unravel the characteristics of cancer cells and cancer. Starting with a broad, general introduction to cancer as a pathology that has had an impact on human life worldwide since prehistoric times, students then cover, step-by-step, each scientific breakthrough that led to the modern view of what entails cancer pathogenesis, each lecture focusing on one hallmark of cancer. Each lecture follows the same blueprint, in the sense that students navigate through each topic by addressing a specific molecular characteristic associated with cancer cells while highlighting the discrepancies with non-cancer cells. One session is a problem-based learning case, during which students play the role of a multidisciplinary care group and try to determine whether the patients present tumorigenic lesions by using notions and tools studied throughout this two-week course. This course, as an attractive combination of lecture and discussion, gives students a strong scientific background on basic cell biology properties such as cell division and DNA replication, but also a solid introduction to oncogenesis with more intricate topics such as oncogenes and the metastasis process. Due to the nature of the two-week Pre-College Program, no wet lab experiment is conducted in this course.

BIOS P-13512.course_name: Molecular Oncology: Unravelling Molecular Biology Techniques
BIOS P-13512.course_description: This course explores the main molecular pathways and biomolecular techniques used in the lab through the prism of cancer research. The purpose of this course is to give students who have a background in cancer biology a unique and thorough view on how to perform, interpret, and criticize laboratory experiments. After a brief review of what cancer is as a disease, the course dives into the molecular pathways seen in oncology and specific molecular techniques. Our journey begins by looking at how the study of tissue formation during embryogenesis leads to the tumor classification that we now use, and we unveil how this was made possible by specific histological and biochemical tools. Then, we direct ourselves toward the understanding of how genes and protein deregulation control the fate of cancer cells. We dwell on the biomolecular techniques developed to monitor the cell cycle progression, DNA replication, genes, and proteins expression. The concluding part of the course consists of a problem-based learning case designed to help students understand how biomolecular techniques influences cancer medicine. Hence, this course gives students a fresh review on basic cell biology properties, such as cell division, DNA replication, and cell death, but also a solid introduction to oncogenesis with more intricate topics including proto-oncogenes and oncogenes, and the relationship between tumor and the environment, focusing on metastasis process, angiogenesis, and the role of the immune system on cancer. More importantly, the course covers the main laboratory molecular biology techniques used in labs worldwide. Due to the nature of the two-week Pre-College Program, no wet lab experiments are conducted in this course.

BIOS P-13516.course_description: This course aims to introduce students to the field of developmental biology. We address questions such as: how does our body form? How are the specialized cells in our tissues generated and how are they normally replaced due to routine wear and tear? How can we use this information to try to generate these same types of cells in a dish? How do our organs form in the locations they do and how do they know how big to become?

BIOS P-13525.course_description: Western medicine has historically focused on the mechanics of how we get sick, but is now starting to ask another question: why do we get sick in the first place? This course introduces students to evolutionary medicine, a growing field that applies evolutionary principles to understand health and disease. The course begins by building a foundation of basic evolutionary concepts and an understanding of human evolutionary history. Students apply these concepts to attempt to understand medical conditions. Specifically, we address the questions: are allergies more common today than in the past? Why might some populations be at higher risk for diabetes? Why do we get cancer? Finally, we investigate the feasibility and controversies of applying evolutionary perspectives in modern medical practice. Students in this course develop research skills to evaluate claims about human health both in the classroom and in their everyday lives. Students learn how to search for and identify appropriate academic sources and strengthen their oral and written communication skills through group discussions, presentations, and short papers.

BIOS P-13527.course_description: When we think of the natural world, we usually focus on individual animal and plant species. However, no individual, population, or species lives in a bubble. In fact, the life of any plant or animal is heavily dictated by its interactions with other organisms and various environmental factors. This course is an introduction to synecology—also known as community ecology—an ever-expanding field that seeks to explain the processes that underlie biodiversity, community structure, and the distribution and abundance of species through space and time.

BIOS P-13530.course_description: This course is designed to introduce students to the concept of epigenetics and how it relates to the heritable phenotypes without changes in the underlying DNA sequence. The course objectives are for students to understand the difference between genetics and epigenetics, to become familiar with various basic epigenetic mechanisms and how they are regulated, to learn about different molecular methods/techniques and model organisms used commonly in epigenetics research, and to relate their knowledge of epigenetics to human diseases. Readings from recent primary literature and review articles, and active class discussion are emphasized. The final project is a culmination of the knowledge acquired throughout the course. Students submit a mock grant proposal and make revisions in response to comments they receive. This exercise allows students to conduct research on an original topic of their choice related to epigenetics and to experience what it is like to be a principal investigator in academia submitting their ideas to the National Institute of Health.

BIOS P-13532.course_name: DNA, RNA, and Beyond: The 'Omics Revolution
BIOS P-13532.course_description: 'Omics informally refers to the branches of science with the suffix "-omic" in their name. These include fields such as genomics (genome or DNA), transcriptomics (transcriptome or RNA), proteomics (proteins or amino acids), metabolomics (metabolism), and lipidomics (lipids). Advances in sequencing technologies over the past few decades have rapidly increased the speed and decreased the cost at which data can be generated, allowing unprecedented insight into the world at a molecular level. This course strives to provide an understanding and appreciation of the technological advancements in sequencing, the 'omics fields which have formed as data becomes readily available, and the role that 'omics data plays in everything from health to criminology to ancestry tracing. Students engage in readings of current and seminal articles both independently and during in-class discussions. Additionally, students work in groups to write a mock grant proposal in one of the 'omics fields covered in class. In doing, so students have the opportunity to integrate what they have learned in class with ideas of their own regarding 'omics data, submit a draft, and respond to review comments.

BIOS P-13533.course_name: Dating, Relationships, and Marriage: Biological and Cultural Perspectives
BIOS P-13533.course_description: From adolescence onward, humans dedicate a substantial amount of time and effort toward managing romantic relationships. Influenced by a combination of biological instincts and cultural norms, we are driven to seek, evaluate, and secure partners—and the choices we make in forming relationships are some of the most defining aspects of our lives. Beyond our own relationships, we display a deep concern with those of other members of society: our social circles gossip about who is dating who as our politicians make laws about who can marry who. We even obsess over the sex lives of fictional characters. In this course, we investigate dating, relationships, and marriage in humankind from both biological and cross-cultural perspectives. In the first half of the course, students learn about the evolution of sexual reproduction, mating systems in the animal kingdom, the neurochemistry of attraction and pair-bonding, and sexual development in humans. In the second half, our attention shifts to the cultural evolution of marriage. We explore diversity in dating and marital customs across societies, derive the emergence of the ideal of monogamy, and examine current trends in dating and marriage.

BIOS P-13535.course_name: Epidemiology and Biostatistics with R Programming
BIOS P-13535.course_description: This course is designed to introduce students to basic concepts of epidemiology and biostatistics, with hands-on programming in R. Students learn about epidemiological study designs and statistical methods used in published studies. Furthermore, they perform their own study and make new discoveries by analyzing primarily the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) dataset.

BIOS P-13552.course_description: This course introduces fundamental concepts of genetics at the molecular, cellular, organismal, and population levels. We study the DNA molecule, replication, modes of transmission, the interplay between genotype and the environment to achieve phenotype, and population variation that leads to evolutionary change. Both human and non-human examples are discussed. Lecture topics are reinforced with readings from primary literature, guided discussions, and laboratory activities.

BIOS P-13555.course_description: Microbes surround us—inside and out. This course introduces students to the microbiomes of our bodies and environment and their influence on human health. We begin by discussing the microbial world, types of different microbiomes, and why a healthy dose of skepticism is needed regarding microbiome science. In week two, we focus on the role of the gut microbiome in health and disease. Finally, we discuss the promise and pitfalls of harnessing microbial science to influence human health and whether the hype has gotten ahead of the science. Throughout the course, we discuss the concept of a healthy microbiome and the persistent dichotomy of good and bad microbes. Students in this course develop critical thinking and research skills to evaluate claims about microbial science both in the classroom and in their everyday lives. Students learn how to search for and identify appropriate academic sources and strengthen their oral and written communication skills through group discussions, presentations, and short papers.

BIOS P-13557.course_description: This course is an integrative exploration of human metabolism, answering the broad questions of how and why our bodies use energy in our day-to-day lives. All living organisms receive energy from the outside world, transform it in their bodies, and then expend it on vital life processes including creating more life through reproduction. Human metabolism is like other animals in many ways, yet unique and derived in important aspects. In this course we explore human metabolism from the molecular level to the ecological level using the lens of evolution to understand the various processes that make up metabolism, as well as their interactions and integration across a person's body. The course includes a review of energetics, thermodynamics, and molecular physiology followed by in-depth study of molecular and cellular metabolism and the processes of digestion and substrate utilization. We then zoom out to study energy allocation and metabolic regulation within specific tissues and across the entire body, exploring behavioral and hormonal control of the underlying processes. The course finishes by looking at metabolic ecology, the decisions people make about activity and food and the effect of variation in human lifestyles on metabolism, and the evolution of the unique human metabolic strategy since our divergence from our ape ancestors.

BIOS P-13565.course_name: Climate Change: A Deep Time Perspective
BIOS P-13565.course_description: Since the industrial revolution, humans have emitted massive amounts of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases into the atmosphere at a rapid rate, causing increases in temperature, acid rain, ocean acidification, and desertification. However, the last 200 years are not the only period of drastic environmental change in Earth's history. In the 4.5 billion years since forming, Earth has experienced an atmosphere devoid of oxygen, been covered by glaciers, and hosted mass extinctions caused by both increases and decreases in temperature. This course aims to give students a deep-time perspective on Earth's climate, insights into the mechanisms controlling it, and the impacts of those changes. Students get hands-on experience examining and evaluating the supporting evidence during lab activities in addition to reading primary literature. We start by understanding Earth as a system, what the current state of that system is, controlling factors on climate, and how climate changes. The course then focuses on individual periods of dramatic climatic shifts including oxidation of the atmosphere (2.5 billion years ago), global glaciation (720-635 million years ago), sea level drop from global cooling (443 million years ago), massive volcanism (254 and 66 million years ago), asteroid impact (66 million years ago), and the impact of planetary cycles. Understanding the causes and consequences of past climatic events prepares students to better examine the current period of global climate changes and potential futures of Earth. Each class includes time for paper discussion, lectures on new material, and lab activities focused on evaluating evidence. For the final project, students select a policy or regulation that could mitigate the impacts of climate change. They research what the policy aims to address, how it would work, and its potential effectiveness before presenting on the last day of class. This course gives students a strong scientific background in data interpretation and evaluation as well as a deep understanding of Earth's climatic history and potential future.

BIOS P-13570.course_description: This course introduces basic concepts related to the epidemiology, pathology, and treatment of infectious diseases. Both human pathogens and zoonotic examples are discussed. Lecture topics are reinforced with readings from primary literature, guided discussions, and laboratory simulation activities.

BIOS P-13571.course_description: This course covers human physiology and pathophysiology of selected organs via lectures, readings, and focused group discussions. The primary focus of the course is on cardiovascular, pulmonary, renal, and gastrointestinal systems, as well as endocrinology, cancer, and immunology. The goal of the course is to prepare high school students for a pre-medical track, research internships in pathophysiology, or advanced courses in physiology by providing solid foundation in physiology and pathophysiology tailored according to their background, aptitude, and interests. While human biology is of prime focus for this course, some examples are drawn from model organisms. In addition, the basics of recent therapeutic approaches, including gene therapy and genome editing, are covered.

BIOS P-13575.course_description: Parasites interact with all manner of organisms and directly impact the health of their hosts. This course considers traditional aspects of parasitology. Three major groups of animals are discussed: parasitic protozoa, parasitic helminths, and those arthropods that directly cause disease or act as vectors of various pathogens. Basic types and concepts of animal associations are discussed. Then we investigate the major groups of parasites, followed by the morphology, life cycle, pathology, treatment, and control of these species. We also explore molecular mechanisms in the host-parasite relationship, the influence of parasites on the ecology and evolution of their hosts, the modes of action of chemotherapeutic agents, and strategies for the possible eradication of these diseases. Lecture topics are reinforced with readings from primary literature, guided discussions, and laboratory simulation activities.

BIOS P-13580.course_name: Ornithology: The Secret Life of Birds
BIOS P-13580.course_description: With greater than 10,000 species, modern birds are rivaled only by fish and non-avian reptiles as the most diverse extant vertebrate clade. These fascinating animals have captured the interests of evolutionary biologists since the dawn of the field. This course seeks to provide an introduction to these amazing animals from multiple angles. The course begins with a module on the origins and major clades of modern birds. From there, we explore avian anatomy and physiology with a particular focus on traits unique to birds. Subsequently, we cover a broad overview avian senses, flight, breeding system, and evolution. Part of the course provides students the opportunity to get up close and personal with the Harvard Ornithology Collection (the largest university-based ornithology collection in the world) and explore unique features of birds from around the world.

CLAS P-10100.course_name: Family Drama: Crime, Destiny, and Tragic Kinship
CLAS P-10100.course_description: They mess you up, your mom and dad. This sentiment, paraphrased from the English poet Philip Larkin, has inspired some of the most profound art in human history. Family can be a safe space: it is a source of profound love, immense sacrifice, and courageous solidarity. But family may also threaten grave dangers: old resentments blossom, new disputes loom, and the weight of ancient wrongs is never fully relieved. In this interdisciplinary course, we explore the transgressive acts committed in the name of family—for love, for rage, for vengeance—as well as the artistic dialogues surrounding them through the ages. This journey begins with some of the most notoriously dysfunctional families ever depicted—those of Heracles, Medea, Oedipus, and Agamemnon in the tragic dramas of ancient Greece. Devoting particular attention to the theatrical construction of gender in family relationships, we consider how Athenian drama figured in the societal controversies of its time and why it continues to be relevant today. With these dramatic works as our template, we move to their contemporary analogue in The Godfather cinematic trilogy, in which notions of family honor spur shocking acts of violence. Throughout the course, we have frequent opportunity to consider why visions of fate, criminal wrongdoing, and inherited guilt continue to haunt popular depictions of family even today.

CREA P-10303.course_name: How to Write an Unforgettable Short Story
CREA P-10303.course_description: The short story is among the most challenging forms in all of literature. Stories offer the psychological and emotional depth of novels, but in a highly condensed form. In this fast-paced course, students learn how to write stories by studying the work of our most exciting and accomplished modern writers, including James Baldwin, Lorrie Moore, Raymond Carver, and Zadie Smith. We also take on the major elements of craft, from plot and pacing to character and chronology. Students write stories every day, to learn by doing, and finish the course with a portfolio that represents the best of their work.

CREA P-10320.course_description: We are all at least vaguely familiar with the term creative nonfiction. But what exactly does it mean to do nonfiction creatively? Are journalists creative writers? Historians? Doctors? Does it depend, and if so, on what? Designed for first-time writers of creative nonfiction, this course pushes students to read across a broad swathe of topics, forms, and craft techniques to begin exploring this rich and capacious genre. Along the way, we take our cues from some of history's most incisive essayists—including James Baldwin, Joan Didion, Vivian Gornick, Atul Gawande, and John Jeremiah Sullivan—and use what we learn to draft two substantive essays to be workshopped by the class.

CREA P-10330.course_description: This is a workshop-based course for beginning-to-intermediate writers of creative nonfiction. Over the course of the semester, we explore the different ways humor is used across a wide range of nonfiction modes—from personal essays, to criticism, to satire—as both a literary tool and a goal unto itself. We also look at the way that form, audience, and persona shape the way we engage with humor, both as readers and writers of creative nonfiction. Along the way, we take our cues from a range of contemporary humorists—including David Sedaris, Samantha Irby, Mindy Kaling, Stephen Colbert, and Dave Eggers—and use what we learn to craft two substantive humor essays to be workshopped by the class.

CSCI P-14115.course_name: Introduction to Data Science with a Focus on Visualization
CSCI P-14115.course_description: This course is a short introduction into the world of data science with a heavy focus on visualization. The course is split into two parts. In the first week, students learn to use Python to compile clean and convenient-to-use data sets from the web and explore this data through visualizations using the Python library Matplotlib. This first phase concludes with a two-day in-class guided mini project, in which students use their newly acquired knowledge to create visualizations based on COVID-19 infection data. In the second week, we take an in-depth look at visualizations and their communicative potential. Together, we create more complex and dynamic visualizations using JavaScript. Throughout this course, we guide students through the computational analysis of different data sets, starting with web scraping and data cleaning and ending with implementing sophisticated visualizations to present findings. We do not lecture about computational data analysis or computer programming; rather, students learn about these things deeply, collaboratively, and in an environment where everyone is dependent upon each other's contributions.

DGMD P-14515.course_name: Digital Media: Society, Culture, and Economics
DGMD P-14515.course_description: How did our lives come to be shaped by computers? Is the internet a tool for liberation or control? What future can we envision for society as it becomes increasingly virtual? This course provides an introduction to the role of digital media in culture, economics, and politics in order to explore these questions. Through daily readings, assignments, and films, students consider technology such as online social networks, computer generated imaging, and the iPhone, in relation to current debates including the place of digital media in cultural production, political activism, and the global workplace. The course focuses on developing students' core academic skills, such as analyzing and evaluating texts, effective writing, verbal communication, and working within a group. The course also includes virtual field trips to relevant resources located at Harvard, including the Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments and Fogg Museum of Art. An understanding of digital media is highly advantageous for students embarking upon their college careers.

ECON P-16525.course_description: The goal of this course is to give broad insight into the micro- and macroeconomic effects of invention and innovation. Nobel Prize Laureate Paul Krugman once noted that while productivity is not everything, it is, in the long run, almost everything. A country's ability to improve its standard of living over time depends almost entirely on its ability to raise its output per worker. Doing so demands leveraging the power of technology in sectors like energy, medicine, and transportation. Innovations in these sectors include drills that can bore deeper, drugs that have a longer shelf life, and airplanes that can fly further—all of which have worked to alter economic status quo. This course explores the consequences—both good and bad—that technological progress has on consumers, firms, and governments. Particular attention is paid to how advances in medicine effect social security, the impact of engine technology on bilateral trade policy, and the effect of automation on wages (such as the company Uber).

ECON P-16560.course_description: The need to develop personal finance literacy is an increasingly important issue worldwide, especially in the wake of the latest financial shocks and the COVID-19 pandemic crisis. The large majority of households do not possess the basic knowledge of financial concepts necessary to effectively manage personal finances and achieve a lifetime of financial well-being. This course aims to bridge this gap by providing students a grounding in the fundamental principles and skills of financial planning. It focuses on the analysis of the major topics of personal finance and stresses the importance of behavioral biases that households confront every day in trying to reach their financial goals. The course is structured to meet the needs and expectations of prospective undergraduate university students, looking to build their skills to create and ensure a financial well-being throughout their lives.

ENVR P-10100.course_description: Climate change is one of humanity's most pressing contemporary issues. Though the science is abundantly clear regarding humankind's anthropogenic influence, there remains staunch disagreement regarding how the problem should be framed and understood, what exactly should be done about it, and who should take on those tasks. This course delves into these questions by first asking: what kind of problem is climate change? Should climate change be primarily understood as a technical problem, an economic problem, a moral one, or something else? Students investigate different ways of understanding the challenge climate change poses, exploring the advantages and drawbacks of each approach. With an understanding of the problem in hand, we turn towards the second main question: what sort of solutions should we pursue in the fight against climate change? Should the market be the primary tool for addressing the problem? Should we rest our faith in technologies like carbon removal and solar geoengineering? Or should we focus on living smaller lifestyles and producing and consuming less overall? What should we do if efforts to promote the right solutions end up unsuccessful because of the vested interests of powerful people and corporations? Who is the "we" under consideration in these questions? This interdisciplinary course addresses these questions from the perspective of economics, politics, and ethics, with special attention paid to the way ethical considerations make their way into current ways of framing the climate change problem and proposed solutions. On the last day of class, students put their new understanding of the problem to work during a day of climate action.

ENVR P-10105.course_name: Tsunamis of Inaccuracies: How Natural Disasters Are Depicted in Film
ENVR P-10105.course_description: Earth is a dangerous place, with wildfires, flooding, storms, volcanic eruptions, and earthquakes that threaten human lives. These natural phenomena, which unleash extreme conditions and have captured the imagination of humans, are often inaccurately depicted in film. In this course, we examine some of those movies and analyze their accuracy, while studying how these phenomena occur and comparing them to real-world events. We cover hurricanes, blizzards, tornados, earthquakes, tsunamis, flooding, and volcanic eruptions. How large are tsunami waves? What was the largest hurricane? Where do the strongest earthquakes occur? Understanding how these events occur requires studying geology and the atmosphere, making it an inherently interdisciplinary course. While examining these films, students build skills in critical thinking and problem solving. This course gives students a better understanding of the natural world around them.

EXPO P-10101.course_name: The Art of the College Essay
EXPO P-10101.course_description: This course focuses on crafting a personal essay that can be used as the basis for a college application. Topics to be covered include voice, tone, structure, and different approaches to storytelling. We also pay close attention to the mechanics of writing, including punctuation, grammar, and word choice. The course is conducted as a workshop and students have an opportunity to share their own work. They also read and discuss the work of selected personal essayists, such as Jennifer Egan, Junot Díaz, Ocean Vuong, and Kevin Young.

EXPO P-10110.course_description: What makes college-level essays different from the essays written in a high school English classes? What do college students learn in their first-year writing courses? This course introduces students to college writing by taking them through the steps required to complete a five-page analytic essay. Students read a range of classic and contemporary short stories, and develop strategies for careful close reading via class discussion and in-class exercises. Students complete several short writing exercises leading up to a full draft and revision of a final paper. Along the way, students learn to generate analytic questions, consider counterargument, and support claims with evidence while also developing strategies for writing coherent paragraphs and clear, concise sentences.

GOVT P-14155.course_name: The Politics of the United States Energy Transition
GOVT P-14155.course_description: Climate change presents perhaps the greatest challenge to global and domestic policymaking in the twenty-first century. It threatens to undermine weather patterns, ecosystems, communities, food sources, economic production, commerce, and migration. Mitigating the long-lasting environmental and distributional effects of climate change will involve energy transitions, economic transformations, technological innovations, and collaborative decision making. Finding and implementing solutions to this pressing issue, however, requires overcoming a key obstacle—politics. In this course, we explore the politics of the energy transition in the United States. We rely on insights primarily from political science, but also consult economics, sociology, public policy, and environmental science. We consider how the energy transition affects industrial sectors, such as manufacturing and fossil fuels, as well as the communities on the front lines of both economic and climate change. We evaluate why some decarbonization policies are more successful than others and how different regions of the country may take different approaches to climate mitigation. We also take into account the obstacles to collective action around the energy transition by examining public opinion and interest group engagement in climate politics. We conclude by highlighting potential paths forward for meeting domestic and global climate goals.

GOVT P-16110.course_name: Democracy, Development, and Violence: An Introduction to Comparative Politics
GOVT P-16110.course_description: Why are some countries democracies and others are not? Why are some countries rich and others poor? Why are some countries stable, while others spiral into violent conflict? This course engages students with major theories and foundational ideas from political science that seek to answer these big comparative questions. In doing so, the course introduces students to the field of comparative politics and to the practice of social scientific inquiry. The substantive focus of the course through the first week is on democracy. When do democracies fail? How do countries become democracies, and why do some get there but not others? And finally, how do dictatorships work? We consider cases from eighteenth-century France to the fall of authoritarianism in Latin America and Eastern Europe in just the past few decades. The second week surveys the remainder of the comparative politics literature across two big topics: economic development and conflict. Why are some countries rich and others poor? We examine economic successes like Singapore and South Korea as well as failures like Kenya and Venezuela. Why are some countries stable, while others experience violence and conflict? We compare political violence from medieval Europe to current-day Afghanistan and Pakistan. Through the lens of these three big topics—democracy, development, and conflict—students receive a broad lay of the land of the field of comparative politics. The course also focuses on three skills: reading, writing, and scientific inquiry. Students independently read published academic books and articles, while receiving in-class guidance on how to read the kind of professional scholarship they would be expected to consume in college. Students generate their own research designs on a social science question of interest and have an opportunity to present their designs to their peers in a simulated conference setting. Finally, students learn basic principles of scientific inquiry, with an emphasis on the comparative method and on the distinction between the social sciences, the humanities, and public policy.

GOVT P-16116.course_description: This course introduces students to the theory and practice of American grand strategy. We cultivate the knowledge and skills to engage in a series of grand strategic debates, including what role the United States should play in the world, what foreign policy instruments most effectively advance US national interests, and what the biggest challenges the United States faces today. Should the United States lead from behind or lead from up ahead? Is the liberal international order truly liberal? Do alliances deter wars or start them? Why are US-Russia and US-China relations so adversarial today, and can anything be done to manage these tensions?

GOVT P-16145.course_name: The Politics of Health and Medicine in the United States
GOVT P-16145.course_description: How does politics shape health in America? In this multidisciplinary course, students explore the historical origins of institutions like Medicare and Medicaid, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and the National Institutes of Health (NIH). We seek to explain the politics of why American healthcare policy differs so dramatically from its peers, with narrowly targeted public programs and a dominant private insurance sector. Students learn how epidemiologists and clinicians today think about social determinants of health, especially racial disparities in care and outcomes. We conduct deep dives into topics like the Affordable Care Act, COVID-19, reproductive health, and the medical ecosystem here in Boston. Finally, students also observe how public health researchers make use of social science methods, from the clinical trial to the ethnographic case study.

GOVT P-16150.course_description: Every year, criminal organizations like mafias, drug cartels, and street gangs claim hundreds of thousands of lives. Across the developing world—and even in parts of industrialized countries such as Italy, the United Kingdom, and the United States—millions more live under the tight control of criminal groups. In such places, it is impossible to fully understand politics, economics, or even day-to-day life without understanding how criminal organizations work—and how they (re-)shape the world around them. This course draws on insights from political science, sociology, and economics to unpack the black box of criminal organizations. The course is organized in three sections. First, we explore the nature and origins of four dominant types of criminal groups: mafias (with a focus on the Sicilian Mafia), trafficking organizations (with a focus on Mexican drug cartels), street gangs (with a focus on MS-13), and prison gangs (with a focus on the Brazilian PCC and American prison gangs). Next, we explore the consequences of criminal organizations for the societies in which they operate, with a focus on violence, governance, corruption, and democracy. Finally, we search for solutions: what, if anything, can governments do to address organized crime effectively? Throughout the course, most of our evidence comes from Latin America—the world's current organized crime hotspot—but we also look at examples from Italy and the United States.

GOVT P-16170.course_name: Generative Artificial Intelligence: From the Basics to the Policy Implications
GOVT P-16170.course_description: ChatGPT, Bard, and Midjourney, along with similar generative artificial intelligence (AI) tools, are the subject of the news and heated public debate. They are poised to reshape how we learn, work, and play. In this course we explore the scientific principles underlying generative AI. Armed with this background knowledge, we then delve into some of the policy and governance issues linked to these technologies. Amongst other things, we explore the potential impacts of generative AI on the arts, education, labor markets, the legal system, journalism, and cybercrime.

GOVT P-16171.course_name: Beyond Law and Code: The Governance of Emerging Technologies
GOVT P-16171.course_description: This course delves into the complex and multi-faceted world of technology governance—a critical aspect of shaping the way technology impacts society and vice versa. In addition to traditional lawmaking, governance encompasses a broad range of venues and mechanisms within the private and public sectors, nationally and internationally, both binding and non-binding. This course aims to equip policymakers and other stakeholders with the insights and tools needed to navigate this complex tech governance ecosystem. Students learn how to map the key governance venues relevant for a given technology issue and how those venues interact, identify leverage points within this ecosystem where small changes can have maximum impact, and pick the right policy tools (including non-traditional ones) to effect change.

HIST P-13021.course_name: Immigrants and the American State since 1882
HIST P-13021.course_description: This course traces the history of immigration to the United States and the changing definition of what it means to be a citizen and a foreigner. Proceeding chronologically since the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 and the establishment of the immigration processing center at Ellis Island, all the way to Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) and immigration in the twenty-first century, we trace the evolutions of migration and citizenship policies and how this shaped immigrants' experiences. Certain recurring themes are guiding threads throughout this chronological exploration. We look at the ways the state has controlled membership in the citizen body and how ethnicity, race, gender and empire shaped access to the country and to citizenship. Then, we explore the different ways foreigners were identified and categorized and the changing landscape of immigration administration: the census, alien registration, border enforcement, internment, detention, and deportation. Finally, we explore forms of control directed at foreign populations, directly with policies such as alien registration and Japanese internment, and through policies targeted indirectly at foreigners, like Prohibition or the Red Scare.

HIST P-13026.course_name: American Histories of Witchcraft and the Supernatural
HIST P-13026.course_description: How has the Anglo-American and later US colonial project transformed our supernatural world throughout its expansion over North America? Historically, how have notions of gender permeated our understandings of that which we deem otherworldly? And how can we pick up the threads of this enlivened world in the material objects left behind by those who precede us? This course seeks to uncover the magics hidden, punished, and valorized in American history. We inquire how the preternatural world and the practices which ground it in our day-to-day life intersect with the gendered body and modes of healing. Ultimately, this is an exploratory course for students interested in learning how to approach, understand, and discuss the deep history of American magics, witchcrafts, and supernaturals. Class time is loosely structured around lecture, discussion, exercises engaging with material cultures, and visits to specific locations on campus, including the Harvard Art Museums. For their final project, students have the opportunity to play with the supernatural by developing their own ritual, specifically by utilizing themes learned throughout the course.

HIST P-13031.course_description: This course examines the history of the relations of the United States with the rest of the world since the Spanish-American War, providing students with an overview of the transformations of American policy as well as the evolutions of world history over this period. We trace the evolutions of US foreign relations through overseas colonial expansion, the rise of trade and economic power, the world wars, cold war diplomacy and interventions, to the period following the fall of the Soviet Union. Through this chronological exploration, we examine the role of ideology in foreign relations, the competing forces of interventionism and isolationism, and the link between domestic politics and foreign policies. This course also encourages students to consider actors in foreign relations beyond the state, teasing out the variety of governmental actors from the executive to the legislature, the army, and state agencies, and taking into account the role of individuals, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and international organizations.

HIST P-13043.course_description: In the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, white revolutionaries fought in North America, France, and Spanish America for independence from imperial control and for ideals such as equality and liberty. In doing so, they built new nations founded upon the language of universal freedom. As new definitions of liberty swept the revolutionary Atlantic, enslaved people living within these new nations remained in bondage. During the age of revolutions, enslaved people across the New World, from Brazil to New York, embarked on their own revolutionary journeys that ran counter to the wars of independence in the Americas and the French Revolution. In doing so, they reshaped notions of freedom, community, and Black identity in ways that are fundamental to present day society. This course examines slave rebellions and resistance to slavery in the Atlantic world. Students learn about the history of slavery and the history of Black opposition to slavery. Students also work to better understand what liberty and bondage, words so commonly used rhetorically by the founding fathers, meant to enslaved people in the New World. The aim of this course is to broaden students' understandings of the history of slavery during the age of revolutions and to prepare students for college-level course work in the field of history.

HIST P-13046.course_name: Literature as History: Toni Morrison and Chinua Achebe
HIST P-13046.course_description: Although too often kept apart from one another, literature and history both work toward a common end. They aim to guide their students through the difficult and opaque experiences of human beings in the past and present. This course considers two major novels of the twentieth century as historical novels. Both novels—Toni Morrison's Song of Solomon and Chinua Achebe's Things Fall Apart—are motivated by historical change and have something to say about the historical events during which they are set. By reading these novels, students learn about colonization in West Africa and internal migration in the United States of America. More importantly, they try to understand what fiction, as opposed to historical non-fiction, can offer to our understanding of the past. In doing so, they meditate on how history and literature can help us to understand ourselves and our lives. Students can expect to improve their reading ability, hone their writing, and develop a more robust sense of the past.

HIST P-13056.course_description: One out of every five people in prison across the world is imprisoned in the United States. Since the 1950s, the nation has experienced an enormous expansion of law enforcement and the criminal justice system that has touched every aspect of American life; hundreds of billions of dollars are spent each year building and maintaining enormous compounds that contain thousands of people; millions of ex-felons cannot vote in states like Florida and Michigan; and in 2016, one in 38 persons were under some form of correctional supervision. For tens of millions of Americans, especially those who are poor, African American, Hispanic, or Native American, the prison system is the most well-funded and consistent presence of government in their lives. How did this happen? What were the historical forces, actors, and events that created this system of incarceration? Does it need to be this way? Can we as a nation respond to the problems of crime and drug addiction differently? What could alternatives look like? This course unpacks the historical origins of mass incarceration in the United States from the decades of Prohibition and internment in the 1920s and 1930s to our recent past with the War on Drugs in the 1980s and the immigration detention programs of the Trump administration in the late 2010s. It aims to help students understand the social, political, and public policy history of jails, prisons, and policing agencies to make sense of the evolving institutions of crime, criminality, confinement, and criminal justice in modern America.

HIST P-13080.course_name: The Transition to Capitalism in the United States of America
HIST P-13080.course_description: Many facets of contemporary American life are so common that they are often assumed to be obvious. Few Americans question why they must exchange their work with employers for a wage, purchase food in the form of commodities from store owners, and pay either a landlord or bankers in order to shelter themselves from the elements. Answers to these basic questions about the fundamental social relationships of American life are anything but self-evident. In order to be satisfyingly answered, these questions require historical analysis. In this course, students embark on the task of explaining these fundamental relationships by analyzing some of our society's formative experiences. In other words, they make sense of the transition of capitalism in the United State of America. Topics of study include capitalism as a concept, the colonization of North America, industrialization, slavery, and the Civil War and Reconstruction. Students enrolled in this course can expect to improve their reading ability, strengthen their understanding of the historical method, and come to terms with the importance of the past for the present.

HIST P-13085.course_name: Worlds of Destruction: The Weimar Republic and the Nazi Seizure of Power
HIST P-13085.course_description: This course explores the way in which democracy in Germany between 1919 and 1933 collapsed under the weight of movements that, to their core, sought to undermine it. It covers the creation of the Weimar Republic in the wake of the First World War, tracing, from its political origins to the development of its culture, worsening political and economic crises over the course of the 1920s to the rise of the Nazi movement, before ending with the Nazi seizure of power in 1933. Throughout the course, students are asked to balance the readings for each class with a relevant primary source. The first hour of each class consists of a lecture, followed by a break, before reconvening for a seminar-style discussion on the assigned readings in addition to a new primary source to be selected by the instructor for each discussion. Students then break down this new primary source with one another in order to place it within the larger context of the day's lecture and other readings. The goal of this course is to help broaden students' understanding of their role as citizens and scholars, to help expand their understanding of the fragile nature of democracy and the consequences of nationalism, and to help them engage in the production of history through an analysis of primary and secondary sources.

HIST P-13090.course_name: Creation as Story: The Power of the Ordinary in Histories of the Everyday
HIST P-13090.course_description: In this course, students are encouraged to think about the process of craft as a historical analytic. This course is designed around six distinct micro-histories, each focusing on a craft unique to its time and place. This includes 'zines in the southern California punk scene; eight-star quilting in the windswept communities of the Great Plains; poppets in Salem amid the witch-panic of the seventeenth century; and basket-weaving among the Wabanaki in what is today called Maine. Each is meant to engage different aspects of craft and society, including race, gender, class, and sexuality, to reveal the power of the ordinary in the lives of everyone. Each micro-history is accompanied by a workshop, whereby students engage in the kind of crafting discussed that day. In each of the two weeks, students participate in one outing, including one visit to the Harvard Art Museum and one to the Houghton Library.

HIST P-13095.course_name: Echoes of the Past: Indigenous Retellings of Conquest and Colonialism
HIST P-13095.course_description: The history of colonial Latin America has often been told from the Spanish point of view. But how did indigenous people living under colonialism tell the story of Spanish invasion? How did they recall and narrate events that pre-dated Spanish presence? How do historians tell the story of past lives that were almost entirely left out of the historical record? This introductory course to the history of colonial Latin America encourages students to tackle these and other challenging questions in an effort to better comprehend indigenous understandings of the past. Together, we explore the many ways native people told stories about what had transpired, including their use of oral histories, material culture, and unique recording devices. We also learn from the wide array of methodologies that historians and other scholars have employed to unearth the history of indigenous people. A main objective of this course is to introduce students to foundational methods of historical enquiry; for this purpose, we explore a diverse set of primary and secondary sources that draw on examples from both North and South America. Daily required readings give students the opportunity to hone critical reading and analysis skills, as well as to become familiar with diverse scholars' takes on some of the most important and controversial questions in the field of colonial Latin American indigenous history. Likewise, in-class discussions give students the opportunity to ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage in fruitful discussions with their peers. We also make several museum visits where students are able to see the material objects that we discuss in class.

HSCI P-13216.course_name: Women, Medicine, and Health in the United States, 1890-Present
HSCI P-13216.course_description: Why do people who identify as women make up only one-third of the practicing physicians in the United States? How do gender beliefs influence medical knowledge and practice? What do we mean when we talk about womens health? This course explores the intersection of gender and medicine in the United States from 1890 to the present, paying particular attention to the ways gender ideology has shaped the development of medical technologies and treatments, the practice of medicine and who practices it, and how patients have experienced medical care. The course is organized thematically and incorporates both historical and contemporary perspectives, focusing on key topics in the history of women's health, including the professionalization of medicine, gender and sex in medical research, the historical focus on reproduction and fertility, the intersection of gender and race, and women's health activism.

HSCI P-13225.course_description: Scientists operate under the guise of objectivity and neutrality, yet past scientists have utilized their positions of power to disseminate biased findings. Namely, scientists in the eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries created the concept of race, which has defined the social, political, and cultural landscape of the Western world. In this course, we explore the origins of Homo sapiens and how debates over our origins led some thinkers to consider human populations as multiple different species. Through a historical lens, we examine how such thinking permeated into society, affected political policy, contributed to the development of biased medical research, justified the management and control of marginalized populations, and fueled movements such as eugenics and white supremacy. Returning to science, we consider empirical genetic evidence and what it reveals about human variation. This allows us to contrast the historical placement of humans into categories with new understandings of human variation as a distribution across the geographic landscape, influenced by evolutionary forces. Finally, we ask how these themes help us understand racial issues today and how science can be an aid in combating racism. Students leave the course as more critical thinkers able to decipher scientific evidence, societal influence on scientists, and their lasting implications.

HSCI P-13245.course_name: States of Mind: A History of Mental Health
HSCI P-13245.course_description: In this course, we examine the emergence and establishment of mental health theory and practice in the West in the twentieth century. We cast a wide net, looking at the histories of both psychiatry and psychology, and we explore historical approaches to mental wellness that fall outside of these fields as well. Students are guided through the histories of psychotherapy, psychoactive drugs, and diagnostic criteria—three critical categories for mental health. We cover the better-known milestones, like Sigmund Freud and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), but we also dig into difficult chapters of the profession's past, like issues of race, gender, and sexuality. The aim of this course is to foster better understanding the history of psychiatric and psychological phenomena, through which we can better understand our own and others' experiences of mental health today.

LSTU P-15101.course_description: This course introduces students to the US legal system by considering several central or important procedural and substantive aspects of American law. Included among the topics covered are the basic structure and function of US legal institutions; basics of subject matter and personal jurisdiction of American courts; the interaction of state and federal law in the American system of federalism; selected doctrines of constitutional law; selected topics pertaining to the American criminal and civil justice systems; and trial by jury.

LSTU P-15115.course_name: Constitutional Law, Civil Rights, and Civil Liberties
LSTU P-15115.course_description: This course provides a broad introduction to American constitutional law and to contemporary debates about civil rights and civil liberties in the United States. Students learn about fundamental principles of constitutional interpretation, the basic legal limitations on governmental power, the relationship between law and society, and arguments around controversial topics such as free speech, freedom of religion, and government surveillance. In the process, students also deepen their understanding of US politics and see how the judiciary often functions as a key player in our political system.

LSTU P-15135.course_name: Creative Law: Artificial Intelligence, Generation Z, and the Intellectual Property Movement
LSTU P-15135.course_description: This course offers an overview of the many ways in which technology has empowered youth to become critically engaged within concepts of education, law, business, and science. Using intellectual property (IP) as a mechanism to study innovation, we examine how generation Z has contributed to creating a market by which they are immensely in a prime position to lead future generations. The course considers artificial intelligence (AI) and IP from a legal and educational standpoint, focusing primarily on creative, ethical norms for AI advances while driving the discussion on what it means to be future leaders of this emerging technology. This interactive course includes readings, films, and visits to some of Harvard University's top AI-driven and innovation research centers. Further, students design their own AI-IP project to include legal protections and ethical considerations.

LSTU P-15140.course_name: Critical Race Theory: Law and Social Movements
LSTU P-15140.course_description: Critical race theory, or CRT, has become a polarizing topic in recent years. The questions at the base of this analytical framework include: is the law colorblind? Should it be? These simple questions also form the basis for our course, where students explore CRT and other philosophies on race, law, and justice. This course covers important touchstones before surveying different approaches and articulations of racial justice through the law. Students are expected to connect topics to current events and attempt to engage with conflicting viewpoints. This course is useful to anyone interested in law, philosophy, history, or social justice.

LSTU P-15145.course_description: This course explores the tapestry of the American legal system through the lens of historical change. We dive into pivotal moments in the nation's history, examining how landmark court cases, constitutional debates, legislation, and the daily operation of the law have reflected and shaped the nation's development. We begin with the colonial period and the English roots of America's unique common law system. Then, we go through the nineteenth century, looking at cases from Marbury v. Madison to Dred Scott v. Sandford and Plessy v. Ferguson. Finally, we unpack the tumultuous changes of the twentieth century and discuss recent court cases, the modern legal profession, and the relationship between law and politics. Through analysis and engaging conversations, students understand the evolution of the contemporary legal system and its historical context, which equips them to study for a potential career as a historian, a lawyer, or both.

MATH P-12155.course_description: Over the past several years, social justice issues have exploded into the national spotlight. Topics such as climate change, structural racism, gerrymandering, and the rise of disinformation regularly dominate the news cycle. What is often left uncovered is the role that mathematics plays in shaping these issues. In this course, students learn the mathematical concepts behind several current social justice topics. They then apply their mathematical knowledge in a series of projects that help them to more fully engage with the topic and better understand the both positive and negative ways that mathematics is used to shape our daily lives.

MATH P-12160.course_description: In 1997, Deep Blue became the first computer to beat a reigning world chess champion. A little over two decades later, the simplest smartphone can outperform the greatest chess minds, and it can also recognize faces, voices, recommend movies, and learn the users' daily routines. Artificial intelligence algorithms are designed to simulate human intelligence processes within computers. Thanks to the great amount of data available in the world, these powerful algorithms are rooted on simpler mathematical concepts borrowed from calculus, geometry, probability, and statistics. In this course we survey several mathematical aspects used in modern data science algorithms, building on single variable calculus, three-dimensional geometry, and elementary statistics. This course also has a computational component, where students design and train neural networks in Mathematica.

MATH P-12165.course_name: Mathematical Modeling for the Biological and Medical Sciences
MATH P-12165.course_description: This course introduces students to the mathematical modeling techniques required in understanding the dynamics of biological systems, laying the groundwork for future studies in the many different biological or medical fields. Fundamental concepts of single-variable calculus and the development of single- and multi-variable differential equation models of dynamical processes in ecology, biology, and the medical sciences. Students learn the art and science of mathematical modeling by developing their own models and adapting and improving models that are widely used in research. The course leverages the python programming language to understand the implications of the models they construct.

MATH P-12175.course_description: Starting with Pythagoras, this course explores the historical development of mathematical ideas. Students explore the development of geometry, number theory, algebra, and concepts of infinity by engaging with problems that thinkers in different eras were interested in solving. This includes prime numbers, regular polyhedra, solving higher-degree polynomial equations, and complex numbers. This course enables students to see the cohesive story of mathematics that can be missed when taking courses on specific topics.

MGMT P-15260.course_description: Self-awareness is essential on the path to authentic leadership. This course uses a variety of self-assessment tools, readings, and discussions to help us understand who we are, our strengths and goals, and how those factors contribute to the type of leader we want to be. It is increasingly important for people to have a clear idea of who they are and their purpose in life in order to navigate their work-life and become confident and inspiring leaders. Authenticity is about the true self; having clarity about and acting based on one's deepest interests, values, and motivations, and most importantly how we can bring our authentic selves into all corners of our lives. Students apply what they have learned from the course to their personal development through in-depth self-exploration. Students also use peer coaching which allows them to explore areas of growth, as well as to develop this important skill set. The course aims to promote skills for students to understand and develop authenticity in themselves.

PHIL P-11100.course_description: This course explores some of the central questions in Western philosophy: do I have free will? What is a good way for me to acquire knowledge? What rights do I have? In pursuing these questions, students read some of the most prominent philosophers living today and in recent past. Throughout the course, students are encouraged to view these thinkers and their ideas with a critical eye. Focus is given to the development of key academic skills such as identifying, analyzing, and evaluating arguments; writing clearly and concisely; and presenting and defending a thesis. By the end of the course, students develop an awareness of some of the major currents in philosophical thought and have the opportunity to reflect on them critically through open, supportive discussion.

PHIL P-11105.course_description: Many important political and social philosophical issues arise in connection with how we address legal questions, and philosophical issues also arise regarding the nature of law and legal reasoning. This course introduces students to a number of these issues and encourages independent critical thinking about them. Included among the questions to be explored are: what is the relationship between law and morality? Is there ultimately a substantial difference between legal reasoning and what seems to be more open-ended reasoning about policies or justice? What justifies society in criminalizing various acts and administering criminal punishment? Under what circumstances (if any) would the law be justified in permitting some persons to be treated differently than others on the basis of gender or sexual preference?

PHIL P-11130.course_description: Who we are depends on the ethical choices we make. What makes our lives good, noble, and meaningful? How can we improve our own lives and what do we owe to friends, family, or strangers? How can we address prevailing social and economic injustices, and how should we navigate moral issues about which people deeply disagree? This course gives students the tools to think deeply about these problems and articulate their own ethical views with precision and confidence. We examine a range of philosophical frameworks such as utilitarianism, deontology, contractualism, virtue ethics, and various philosophical theories of well-being. We then apply those theories to a variety of real-world topics based partly on students' own interests. In previous years these have ranged from the ethics of human life extension, genetic modification, and abortion, to questions about animal rights, freedom of speech, and the dangers of artificial intelligence. Along the way, we learn how to debate these controversial issues clearly, convincingly, and respectfully.

PHIL P-11151.course_description: Following the murder of George Floyd in the summer of 2020, the country experienced a reckoning. We collectively asked how do we become anti-racist—in our personal lives, in our workplaces, in our politics? How should we transform, or perhaps abolish, our political institutions that have historically served racist ends? In this course, we explore these questions from one level back and at a higher level of abstraction. This mode of inquiry is facilitated through engagement with works from philosophy, law, sociology, and history. We ask questions such as: what is racism, and why (and when) is it morally wrong? Do citizens have a duty to obey the law in a racially unjust society? Is it morally permissible for law enforcement to engage in racial profiling? Is mass incarceration best understood as caused by racist motivations? Are prisons inherently racist institutions?
